audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a calm, gentle musical introduction, reminiscent of spa or relaxation music, creating a serene backdrop. This is followed by a male voice, clearly addressing "Flat Earthers", introducing himself as "Zach." Another male voice, identifying himself as "Steve," joins in. They refer back to a previous video, explaining that the "refraction in the atmosphere...was the solution." They then encourage listeners to watch the previous video, with Zach's tone sounding calm and informative.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of star trails from different locations on a flat earth. He is speaking in an informative tone, responding to previous criticism regarding proof of refraction. He mentions concerns about whether refraction could explain the sun's rising and setting, specifically addressing the idea that refraction would make the sun appear higher instead of lower.

The clip starts with a male speaker clarifying, in a somewhat didactic tone, that they added the atmosphere to the flat Earth model using Cinema 4D. He goes on to explain that, in the model, it makes the apparent sun go down rather than the observer. He then shifts responsibility, suggesting that any errors are due to the software itself, Cinema 4D, and directs any disagreements toward the software developers, delivered in a similarly matter-of-fact tone.

The audio clip features a male speaker, explaining an idea related to the sun and atmosphere in a deliberate, measured tone. He posits a hypothetical scenario involving the sun and a layer of the atmosphere, discussing refraction and the apparent position of the sun. He emphasizes that the real sun is always higher and visible from the ground.

The audio clip begins with speech. A male speaker asks what makes the sun go down, mentioning a few theories that might be wrong, before starting to explain one such theory about the atmosphere plane. He suggests perspective can make the sun go down, making a "flat earth model work." He adds that he and the listener believe the atmosphere is thicker, making perspective only a small factor.

The audio begins with a male speaker presenting a scenario about the sun's movement and its apparent appearance, suggesting an experiment and offering an alternative, calling it a theory. He repeats the idea of a theory while explaining their attempt to prove it using a 3D program, expressing confidence but maintaining the "theory" label. The speaker maintains an inquisitive tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing the movement of the real and apparent sun in Cinema 4D. He speaks in a calm, informative tone, mentioning that the apparent sun appears to move faster. The clip transitions to another male speaker who expands on this, explaining the degree measurements and speed relationship between the real and apparent sun, continuing in an informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a diagram made in AutoCAD that uses real elevation angles of the sun. He describes the location and dates used, suggesting the listener try it out themselves. He claims that when angles are drawn accurately, "the sun travels faster the more it moves away from the observer," and explains that the distance between 5 and 6 pm is longer than that of 4 and 5 pm. He then adds that the distance between 12 and 1 pm is close to the speed of the sun on the Tropic of Cancer, the speed of the spinning earth in that location.
He then makes a clarification: that "the apparent sun doesn't travel in a straight line like the real sun does," so "the distance between each hour should not be so exaggerated." He then questions if perspective is the reason why the sun sets on the flat earth, "the more the sun moves away from us the slower it should appear to us, right?" He uses the analogy of a car speeding away on the highway, which appears to slow down as it moves away.

The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing the sun, saying that it doesn't happen with the sun and that it appears "to travel faster". He concludes that perspective isn't the only reason the sun goes down, speaking in a somewhat academic and informative tone. This is followed by a sudden, distinct sound of flatulence, which interrupts the prior speech. Immediately after this, a male speaker states, "Here is how the starfield would look if we remove the atmosplane", spoken similarly in an academic fashion.

The audio begins with male speech, referencing the Canary Islands, Spain, and discussing the field of view of a lens. The speaker talks about the stars, noting they never set because they are too high, also mentioning their altitude is about 4,000 miles, and claims this is accurate. The speech then ends.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a video and comparing it to an original picture, noting that the "video has changed completely" and the "star trails look exactly like the original picture". This is followed by music that sounds like it's in a funk genre, perhaps with some improvisation. Later, the speaker says "Now let's play the two videos side by side".

The audio clip begins with music, featuring a synthesized sound in an electronic style, creating a somewhat serious and tense mood. There is a male voice, speaking calmly, indicating "we can do this from any location, they all work the same". Then there's a transition back to the music. Another male voice, also calm, notes "another test in France" and asks for feedback on the original by saying "Look at it carefully and compare it with the original, and let us know if we're doing anything wrong." The clip concludes with the synthesized electronic music continuing.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the sunrise and sunset in Salinas, California, noting the need for height adjustments but confirming the correct functioning of the "atmos plane." He emphasizes the "atmos plane" as key to solving a puzzle. Underlying the speech is music, which is in an ambient style with a calm and atmospheric tone, featuring synthesized sounds.

The audio clip opens with a man's voice providing a quick view of stars in AutoCAD, emphasizing the stars' altitude, accurate angles, and alignment with modern science. An Excel sheet containing the data used is highlighted. The speaker presents a top view of stars on a flat Earth with an Atmos plane, aiming to demonstrate that the sun and stars rise and set, regardless of the viewer's position. Adjustments to the map and object heights can address any visual discrepancies with real life. He adds the unknown heights of everything and how the real map looks like. He says the Atmos plane makes things in the sky rise and set in Cinema 4D. He says, “If you think that the atmosphere should make things go up instead of down, then please talk to Cinema 4D programmers.” He announces an upcoming discussion in the next video. Throughout this presentation, there's a subtle, mellow background music that creates a calm mood.

The clip begins with male speech in a factual and informative tone, discussing how the atmosphere in a system makes spheres look oblong. The speaker mentions how the moon is almost flat so that the phases work. The speaker then asks the listener to subscribe to their channel, where more videos can be found. A calm instrumental piece plays in the background throughout the speech, creating a thoughtful atmosphere.
